awd_titl_txt: CAREER: The Formation of Stars, Planets, and Moons: Applying Similar Physics to Different Systems and Enhancing Scientific Computing Literacy
awd_abstract_narration:
Astronomers are now convinced that many, if not most, stars are accompanied by planets.  They are interested in learning how planets form, and whether or not the Solar System is representative of the Universe. It is believed that planets formed from a disk of material around the young Sun; this disk is long gone for our Solar System. In this project, the investigator will use computers and his own computer code to model the properties of how such disks form and change under the effects of radiation from the star and magnetic fields.  He will compare his models with observations obtained from space missions and ground-based telescopes. He will work with educators at museums and supercomputer centers to generate visualizations to help the public understand this work.  He will also develop courses and workshops in computational methods for junior researchers and for students at his home institutions.

The proposed program uses the 3-D magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) code Athena++.  The PI will 1) Model the effects of radiation on the accretion process, 2) Construct models of both non-ideal MHD effects and thermal dynamics on the structure of protoplanetary disks, and 3)  Carry out simulations of disks around protoplanets that share similarities with the simulations described in 1 and 2.  He will compare his simulated models with observations from space missions such as Spitzer and Herschel and ground-based telescopes such as ALMA, EVLA, VLT, Subaru, and Gemini.  Finally, he will make predictions for future observations in the next decade with instruments such as the TMT.


This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our group used numerical simulations to understand the common problems in creating stars, planets, and moons, and make connections between theory and observations. Stars are born out of vast clouds of gas and dust, known as nebulae, where gravity pulls material together. Planets form in the rotating disk of material that surrounds a young star, known as a protoplanetary disk. Here, particles of dust and gas collide and stick together, gradually building up into planets. Moons are created in a similar manner, either forming from the debris in a disk surrounding a planet, called a circumplanetary disk, or being captured by a planet's gravity. This intricate formation leads to the diverse array of celestial bodies we observe in our universe.

Our research centers on the radiation processes occurring within both protoplanetary and circumplanetary disks. These processes play a dual role: firstly, they significantly influence the structural configuration of these disks, as radiation is a key factor in determining their temperature. Secondly, the radiation processes are crucial for generating the light that makes astronomical observation possible, thereby serving as a vital link between observing these celestial objects and understanding their physical characteristics.

 

Our research spanned four major areas:

1. Understanding Star Formation: We conducted radiation magneto-hydrodynamical simulations focusing on earlier periods when the protostar rapidly gains mass, known as outbursting phases. We found that during these phases, the disk's material mainly moves inward through its surface, while a strong disk wind is launched. The mass loss rate in the wind matches real observations. We also explored the role of magnetic fields in these disks, suggesting that optical Zeeman observations could directly detect these magnetic fields.

2.Planet Formation in Dusty Disks: We looked at how planets could form in disks around young stars, especially focusing on the behavior of dust and gas. We discovered that the properties of dust, especially its scattering properties and porous structure, are crucial for understanding how much material is in these disks - a key factor in planet formation. The disk could be several times more massive than we thought before. We further suggested that planetary cores can form directly in massive disks through an instability which similarly produces spirals in spiral galaxies.

3. Studying Disks Around Planets (Circumplanetary Disks): We applied our knowledge of disks around stars to those around planets. We proposed that certain clumps observed in protoplanetary disks could be young planets with their own envelopes. Future observations may directly reveal more such planets, enabling us to study planet growth.

4. Linking Theory with Observations: Finally, we compared our theoretical models with data from various space missions and ground-based telescopes. We even employed machine learning techniques to analyze radio observation data, which helped us estimate the mass of newly formed planets. This part of the research was crucial for testing theories against real-world data and making predictions about future observations.

To achieve a broader impact, we carried out a series of educational efforts towards both general public and students/researchers working in the field of computational astrophysics. This field is a relatively new field joining fluid dynamics, computer science, and astronomy.  The major challenges are the lack of public awareness and the lack of proper multidisciplinary training of the students and junior researchers.

 

1. To communicate with general public on the latest scientific development, we worked with visualization experts at Morrison Planetarium, California Academy of Sciences at San Francisco to render one of our simulations for their planetarium show ``Big Astronomy: People, Places, Discoveries''.  Big Astronomy is a multifaceted research and outreach project supported by several partners and funded by the NSF.  It includes the award-winning planetarium show which highlights the diverse people who enable discoveries at world-class observatories in Chile.

 2. With new software packages from modern languages, we can effectively teach students numerical methods through interactive programing environment. Over the past 4 years, I developed a new course: PHYS 404/604 computational physics II. A novel feature of the course is that I exchange programs with students and make the course open source by using Python Jupyter environment and Github.  With these tools, I can comment on and correct the students' programs in real time, even during the lecture.  Another important component of this course is that I worked with the university library to set up the in-person Virtual Reality (VR) lab to visualize the students' simulation data.

3. Numerical tools are increasingly hard to learn and master for new researchers. During 2019, we hosted the first Athena++ workshop at UNLV, with ~70 participants from all over the world.

 

Finally,all students and postdocs that are supported by this grant have also participated in various professional conferences and local outreach activities, including serving as judges in the annual Elementary and Middle School Science Fair.
